Ristorante Sotto Sotto	1	2018-11-06	"AVOID
TERRIBLE EXPERIENCE
BETTER OPTIONS ELSEWHERE
-  was served 3 risottos when I asked for one
column2: and was blamed by the staff that I ordered that many

column1: -  risotto was raw as well
I was quite excited to try this place with two friends. The miscommunication ruined the whole experience for me.

Knowing that the lunch stops at 3pm and that the risotto takes 40 mins to cook. I called in ahead of time to speak to someone around 1:30pm to have my amalfi risotto ready as I was making my way there. I spoke to a server
column2: I informed her that I wanted 1 order of the Seafood risotto for a table of 3 people. I think it was this point where the miscommunication happened. She agreed and said it will be ready for us.

column1: We arrived at 2pm
column2: we spoke to the initial server and I asked him about the risotto
column3: that I called in about. And he's like is it for here or to go? I told him that we were dining in.

column1: We were seated and waited for 40 mins. Before the risotto came out. To our surprise they brought us THREE RISOTTO dishes. Mind you
column2: on the menu the risotto dish serves 2 people. At no point in time between 2pm to 2:40pm there was any clarification on the order. So I asked the server and informed him that I only wanted 1. So he fetched the server that I spoke to on the phone. And she insisted that I ordered 3 Risottos. I tried to explain to her that party was not ready to eat 6 peoples portion of risotto.

column1: My experience is already ruined at this point. I don't know why she would think that I would want 6 people amounts of risotto. I could've tried other things in the restaurant.
The risotto itself looked amazing. So if the food was okay I didn't mind.
Unfortunately the risotto was under-cooked. It had a grainy
column2: sandy texture that stuck to the teeth. I informed my guests
column3: and another one agreed with me. I let the server know
column4: he brought Chef Massimo Renzi tableside and he just told me it was cooked al dente
column5: and that he used carnaroli rice.

column1: So know we're stuck eating extra risotto that was under-cooked. My other friend thought the rice was fine
column2: until he tried the one underneath the top layer. I'm assuming that the chef probably tasted that top layer and thought the other rice cooked as well.

column1: The seafood in the risotto was perfectly cooked but the dish was spoiled under-cooked rice.
I think ultimately the experience was ruined when I got 3 Risottos instead of 1. Which caused the quality of control to go down on the rice.
You will see in the photos that you can see the centre of the rice. Which is an indicator that the rice was raw."

Buca	5	2020-02-16	"One of my new favorite restaurants! Their menu changes constantly
column2: but there are classics that stick around. I visited on Valentine's Day and was pleasantly surprised by how spacious it was inside as the exterior looked unpromising. The entrance can be difficult to find
column3: as you need to walk down an alley facing King St.

column1: The atmosphere inside was perfect for a date night - gently lit and very romantic. All of their meats are cured in house
column2: and you can see it as you walk through the restaurant. Service was unbeatable - our server was very helpful in providing recommendations (as it was our first visit)
column3: and checked on us after each course. Water glasses never went empty
column4: and the table was wiped down frequently.

column1: As for food...
Tonno ($19): albacore tuna
column2: my favourite dish from the evening. I'm a big fan of tuna and this dish was not only visually appealing
column3: it was a delight on the palate. I could probably eat 5 plates of this myself
column4: as it's so light and refreshing. Don't be intimidated by the chilis - it's definitely not a spicy dish.

column1: Nodini ($8): tiny bread knots with garlic and olive oil
column2: they were so crispy I thought they were fried (but they're not!) a must try if you visit
column3: one of their most popular menu items.

column1: Cervello ($10): lamb brains wrapped in prosciutto

column1: Salumi di buca ($32 for 5): we opted for the soppressata and petto d'oca

column3: and easy to see why it's such a popular item on the menu. You can customize your board
column4: choosing between 2-5 meat options (they also offer a cheese board).

column1: Bigoli ($26): duck egg pasta with duck offal ragu
column2: the serving size is small
column3: but the taste was unbelievable. You can tell from one bite that the pasta was made in-house. Since we tried so many things on the menu the small serving size didn't bother me
column4: but if this is all you plan on ordering
column5: you may leave a little hungry.

column1: Pizze bianca ($30): I can't remember the name of the pizza as it was a special menu item
column2: but it was topped with grilled pears and salumi and was an absolute treat. The pizzas here are a decent size
column3: with an ultra thin crispy crust.

column1: Tiramisu ($15): classic Italian dessert

column5: and virtually flavourless.

column1: Buca	5	2020-01-30	"One of the most celebrated names in Italian food in Toronto is Buca. With two locations in the city
column2: Chef Rob Gentile's original restaurant opened in 2009 in the Fashion District. You don't have to look far to find the accolades. Canada's 100 Best Restaurants listed them at #3 in 2015
column6: and #45 in 2019. Toronto Life has them at #39 on their The City's 100 Best Restaurants 2018 list. And blogTO calls them the #1 Best Italian Restaurant in the city. What's the difference between the (original) Fashion District location and the one in Yorkville? It's mainly that the Yorkville restaurant focuses more on seafood offerings while the Fashion District upholds the classics that everyone loves. Both locations are excellent and offer the exact same consistency and high level of culinary perfection.

column1: The word ""buca"" in Italian translates to hole. Which makes sense because the restaurant pretty much resides in one. Formerly a boiler room
column2: the space is now an expansive and gorgeous restaurant comprised of towering ceilings
column3: all of the exposed brick that you could imagine
column4: and industrial-cool light fixtures. Where the Yorkville location feels more polished and modern
column5: this one is rustic and mysterious. It actually feels a bit like dining in a wine cellar
column6: among stacked bottles and wine barrels. Finding the entrance on King Street can be a little bit tricky because the signage isn't extremely obvious and you have to enter through the laneway. Then you proceed down the stairs and into the depths of the subterranean feast that awaits you. I visited on a Saturday evening - for my birthday
column7: no less. The room is always full of customers and a reservation is certainly recommended.

column1: Met by the friendly and professional staff at the bottom of the stairs
column2: our coats were whisked away and we were seated at our table immediately. The experience felt special right from the very start.

column1: In need of a beverage
column2: I found myself looking over the list of seasonal and house cocktails. I also appreciated the addition of virgin cocktails
column3: because there are certainly times when I don't feel like drinking alcohol but still appreciate the opportunity to order something interesting. However
column4: this wasn't one of those times and the seasonal Frutto Divino (Fresh persimmon puree
column5: calvados
column6: chamomile
column7: lime
column8: egg white - $17.00) was calling to me. The persimmon in this 2oz cocktail caught my attention as it's my favourite seasonal fruit around the holidays. The egg white is the component that sealed my decision. This beverage was expertly mixed and tasted grown-up yet sweet at the same time. I loved the punchy zip from the lime and the fragrant sweetness from the persimmon.

column1: The food at Buca is very serious business
column2: although it somehow feels relaxed. The locally sourced
column3: constantly changing menu involves ingredients that are seasonal and source specific. Nose-to-tail cooking is embraced at Buca (which I especially love). The hospitality is also top-notch
column4: with every staff member exuding a welcoming and knowledgeable disposition. I was so ready to eat!

column1: One famed menu item that I'd kept hearing about over and over was the Salumi di Buca (Selection of 5 salumi served with seasonal preserves - $32.00)
column2: a platter of incredible artisan cured meats. So of course the feast began with that. From left to right:

column1: Speck: (which comes with the gnocco fritto
column2: see below).

column1: Petto d'Oca: Cured goose breast
column2: cinnamon
column3: clove
column4: orange.

column1: Salame Toscano: Cured beef sausage
column2: black pepper.

column1: Finocchiona: Cured pork sausage
column2: black pepper
column3: fennel.

column1: Soppressata: Cured beef sausage
column2: calabrese spices.

column1: Salsiccine: Spicy calabrese style pork sausage.
We also added the Gnocco Fritto (Tuscan spiced dumplings
column3: a personal favourite
column4: which was served on the same board. This whole entire situation was heavenly. Served with an acidic eggplant preserve (which served amazingly to cut through some of the fat)
column5: the beautiful presentation of meats ranged from spicy soppressata to a decadent goose breast that tasted like Christmas. Each one was unique
column6: expertly seasoned
column7: and fragrantly herbed. Largely based in seasonal offerings
column8: I want to keep returning to order this so that I can try different meats every time. A beautiful sharing experience.

column1: The gnocco fritto
column2: a warm
column3: pillowy fried bread
column4: especially owns my soul. From the perfectly uniform shape of each one
column5: to the steamy aroma as you tear them apart
column6: these are what dreams are made of. Served with buttery
column7: melt-in-your-mouth speck
column8: an intensely flavourful cured ham.

column1: I also couldn't resist the Nodini (Warm bread knots
column2: olive oil
column3: rosemary
column4: garlic - $8.00). At this point I was willing to accept that this meal was going to be extremely carb-heavy. I mean
column5: who says ""no"" to perfect little bread balls? A golden
column6: buttery crust on the outside that gives way to a warm and soft inside. All soaking in a garlicy bath.

column1: So things were going well.
Next I took my attention to the Paste section because"

column1: Buca	5	2019-08-16	"Dinner for 4 on Thursday - Summer.  We were able to get in but highly recommend you to make reservation.  Two hosts

column1: Buca	4	2018-12-09	"Came here for a friend's birthday dinner
column2: but was only able to stay for a glass of wine and some appetizers. The service is swanky; waiters are able to explain the menu quite extensively
column3: and ours took the craft of wine very seriously (uncertain whether he was a sommelier). There were certain parts in the night where service
column4: however
column5: was surprising and poorer than expected. May I also mention that their website menu isn't up to date? Makes it difficult for a foodie to choose beforehand!

column1: We started with a bunch of appetizers
column2: listed below.

column1: Charcuterie & Cheese Board
We chose an array of five different meats and cheeses
column2: which came served with three different preserves. It was
column3: quite frankly
column4: very shocking that the board didn't come with any bread or crackers. When prompted and asked
column5: the server point blank asked if we'd like to order the light fried bread (gnocco fritto) to go with the cheeses - for another $10! It therefore felt a bit cheap that they wouldn't even offer a bit of bread to accompany the salty cheese and charcuterie. As such
column6: our experience of the board was a bit lacking; it was a little difficult to finish the remnants of the cheese.

column1: We were told that the cured elk is very unique; Baro and one other restaurant in Western Canada are the sole providers of this elk. The elk certainly tasted interesting! The spices used made it taste like gingerbread and Christmas. Haha! A crowd favourite was the spicy salami (salsiccine)
column2: though my favourites were the leaner meats... Unfortunately
column3: can't remember their names!

column1: With regards to cheese
column2: we only hoped that there was some bread. That said
column3: everyone had their distinct preferences. I like milder cheeses
column4: and so enjoyed the parmigiano.

column1: Nodini
This app probably offered the highest value with regards to quantity / price. There were roughly 12 knots
column2: which were flavourful
column3: warm
column4: and had a nice crunch. My only criticism is that they could have been a little softer (I found them a little dense and dry) and they were swimming in a touch too much olive oil.

column1: Parmigiana di Melanzane

This was my favourite appetizer of the evening! The fried eggplant was lightly breaded and wonderfully crisp. The tomato sauce with the tanginess of the ricotta was super delicious and addicting! The appetizer is quite small for its price point
column2: and so we got 2 to share among the 6 of us.

column1: We also ordered two bottles of red wine... It was really nice! Unfortunately I forgot the name
column2: but it was quite medium/full-bodied
column3: without any harsh acidity or dryness
column4: and went down smoothly. The rest of the party continued to order mains and desserts
column5: but I had to leave early.

column1: I was surprised to hear that they don't separate bills - as such
column2: I had to do the math first and pay my part separately. How interesting! I also appreciated the Italian cookie given as a takeaway favour. The amaretti cookie was chewy and doughy
column3: and had a wonderful almond flavour. I loved it!

column1: Overall
column2: I found Buca to be quite pricey with very small portions. Would I go again? Probably not
column3: unless there was a special function of sorts!"

column1: Buca	1	2019-05-22	"We came here (King St location) Tuesday evening to take our guests from Vancouver to a nice dinner. Buca has been my favorite Italian spots in Toronto and has been my top recommendation for good restaurants in the city. We never once had a negative experience at Buca until last night. It was very disappointing to be in such a classy restaurant only to be treated poorly by their servers. We ordered charcuterie and pasta amongst the 5 of us. As we finished our dinner

column1: Buca	4	2018-10-09	"Buca is straight up wonderful!
Great food and great service. Make sure you book ahead if you plan to go on weekends!
Let's get into the review
Atmosphere 7/10

For me this aspect I'd give Buca good but not great. As you enter the doors (be weary the area is under construction and can be difficult to find) you walk down a set of stairs to the host counter where you are promptly greeted and take to your table (we arrived early on a Wed evening and were seating without problem). As we settled in
column2: the restaurant was surprisingly loud for having only half the tables full
column3: but as the evening went on It wasn't straining to have conversation among friends.

column1: Service 8.5/10
Our kind
column2: knowledgable server
column3: Justina
column4: was very helpful throughout the evening. As Buca's menu has many tasty options and each dish has Italian names and it can be a bit tricky to navigate. This was not a problem as Justina was prompt to make some suggestions on top of some ideas our table had in mind for food. Through the duration of the evening she would regularly come to the table with water refill or to just check up and see how we we're doing. A bonus was that she was very well versed with the wine menu and brought 3 sample tastings to the table before we picked the bottle we wanted!

column1: Food 8/10
For fine dine Italian Buca does not disappoint. Though we may not have had some of the keynote dishes the menu has to offer we still managed to have a solid taste of what the restaurant is all about.
1. Nodini (warm bread knots) 8$ (6/10)
This rating isn't to say these were bad. It's a different take on bread that you'd normally get at most Itn. restos. They were warm
column2: crunchy and the olive oil was good. Nothing too special.

column1: 2. Gnocco Fritto w/ Pancetta 10$ (8.5/10)

Another bread like app we had with our charcuterie board. These were fantastic! So fantastic we ordered it twice later on in the meal. Served to you on the charcuterie board these large pillow like pastries are fantastic.  Perfectly salted with an intriguing flavour they become quite addicting.
3. Charcuterie board 21$ (7.5/10)
For this portion of our apps
column2: Justina was quite helpful in making suggestions as to what cured meats would go well. We had the cured pork salami
column3: spicy pork sausage and cured pork leg. The board comes with a side of preservatives to balance the taste.

column1: 4. Funghi Pizza 32$ (8/10)
To start for a pizza this is quite pricey but they do not cheap out on the ingredients they use. Topped with seasonal mushroom
column2: marscapone and gorgonzola
column3: this pizza has flavours that linger in your taste buds after each bite. Well worth it to share if you're in a group.

column1: 5. Seafood pasta w/ octopus
An neat take on a red sauce pasta. Seafood tasted fresh and noddles were perfectly al dente.
6. Bigoli pasta w/ duck ragu and marscapone 24$ (7/10)
Presentation of this dish was very pretty
column2: and the flavour wasn't too bold. Overall it was tasty but i'm not sure if i'd have it again when I go back.

column1: 7. Grilled whole sea bass w/ olives & preserved lemon 42$ (6.5/10)
Fish was fresh tasting but I'm not sure if it's worth the price. Be careful when eating as some bones are still intact. There was some scales on the skin also.
8. Prosciutto Pizza w/ pesto
column2: asparagus and burrata cheese 30$ (7.5/10)

column1: Same crust as the other pizza and the flavours went well together. The pesto added to the flavour of the cured meat and cheese shavings.
9.  layered creme wafer w/ strawberry drizzle 10$ (7.5/10)
This dessert was pretty tasty. Cream layered between 3 wafers sprinkled with icing sugar tasted fresh and simple. A good way to end the night.

Overall Buca is a typical fine dine Italian with a few neat renditions on several dishes. Their attention to detail and the freshness they incorporate into every dish made this a restaurant I will be eager to visit again."

Buca	4	2019-08-23	I came here with my friend on a Saturday night. We started off with the Burrata and it was absolutely delicious with the fresh strawberries. The layers of light and smooth cream paired well with the espresso. I love the subtle bitterness and the strong note of coffee. It's a real delight to have with a glass of the Vino Chinato.

column1: Stelvio	3	2018-12-31	"I really have mixed feelings about this restaurant. I dined here for dinner and tried quite good amount of food from appetizer to pastas. I feel like this place is better for lunch as portions are small and the vibe and lighting in the restaurant was too light for me for an evening dinner. I loved the black and white simple decor
column2: however I would definitely recommend having less light towards evening.

column1: As for the drink
column2: I tried the Pinot Grigio
column3: and I loved it. If you like an easy white wine with notes of sweetness
column4: this would be perfect.

column1: For appetizer
column2: we ordered a cheese and cold cut board. I was not impressed with the selection of cheeses there. There were two types of cheese and two types of cold cuts. Both cheeses tasted very bland and simple. The portion was fairly good though and it came with a honey and house-made jam which was a nice garnish to it. We also got the meatball to share by the server's recommendation. Probably this was my least favorite item. It was different from a usual Italian meatball you imagine
column3: maybe it is the Milanese way. However I did not like it and it was too dry and meaty. We asked for a side tomato sauce so we can dip them in it.

column1: For main
column2: we ordered two different pasta dishes
column3: the Tagliatelle al funghi porcini and Casoncelli alla bergamasca. They make the pastas fresh in house which I think is what makes this restaurant special. The funghi pasta tasted really good and I loved the mushrooms in it
column4: however I felt it was lacking sauce. Casoncelli alla bergamasca was a meat ravioli with some butter sauce on it
column5: however there was just a little butter sauce on it and it tasted very basic to me. I would say both pastas had very small amount of sauce and both tasted very simple."

column1: Stelvio	3	2020-02-15	The decor was nice and the staff were all very friendly and helpful but it was a veeeery long wait for our main course. I had the Tagliatelle special with sausage

column1: Stelvio	1	2019-07-06	The service is terrible and the food is not good enough to make up for the awful service. The one good thing on the menu is the risotto with the veal shank

column1: Stelvio	4	2019-01-08	I love the risotto here. Pricey and there's extra wait time for it

column1: Terroni	4	2019-04-19	"I've always found Terroni (and some other similar Italian restaurants) slightly overpriced for the food

column1: Trattoria Taverniti	4	2020-01-04	"This place is pretty much the definition of a hole in the wall (which full disclosure is in my opinion the best type of restaurant). It's dark and tiny and has very intimate and authentic vibe.

Trattoria Taverniti	1	2019-09-09	"I was craving pizza for supper this evening.  I was walking along College Street and came across Trattoria Taverniti.  It looked interesting and I'd never been there so I thought I'd check it out.

column2: it was fairly empty but filled up pretty quickly.

I paid my bill and was finishing up my wine
column2: getting ready to go.  Then one of the servers asked if I would move to the patio to a high top chair because they needed my table.  I said I wasn't going to be much longer and didn't want to move to a high top (I have a wonky knee).  About ten seconds later
column3: the second server came over and asked me to move and I told her the same thing.  About five minutes later
column4: one of the servers said I really had to leave because they really needed my table.  I just had a sip of wine left and again said I'd be leaving shortly (and did).  I felt a bit uncomfortable because the table next to mine was looking over and wondering what was going on.

column1: The service was just lovely - our server (name I have forgotten unfortunately) was pleasant and FUNNY!  He cracked jokes with us throughout the service which I found nice after a long shitty day at work.  Definitely an extra star for the service.

I ordered the shrimp and mushroom pasta in an olive oil sauce - Linguini DI Mamma Ninetta - this was pretty ok - light and fresh tasting which is what I wanted since I didn't want a heavy cream sauce when I was going dancing later - that would have put me to sleep!.  My only complaint was that the shrimp to mushroom ratio was off - there were only 3-4 shrimp in my dish and it was overloaded with mushrooms.  The portion was pretty big (for me) - enough for 2 meals.
I'd like to check this place out in the summer when the patio opens up!  Overall the food is about a 3 STAR
column2: but the service bumps it to 4 STAR."

column1: Fieramosca	2	2019-07-04	"It is on the $$ side so I expected a great meal. I ordered Spaghetti Carbonara. I can't believe the fatty bacon in this dish. I basically picked out all of the bacon grizzle and ate the spaghetti which
column2: aside from the bacon was good.

column1: The atmosphere in this establishment is uptight. The tables are too close together

column1: Fieramosca	5	2018-11-03	"My favorite Italian restaurant in Toronto. Wonderful service. Elegant

Fieramosca	5	2019-07-07	Had an amazing pasta dish. The pasta was fresh and so was the tomato sauce. The wait staff were all very courteous and kind.
Fieramosca	5	2016-11-04	"Heading out to the ROM for FNL with friends
column2: we wanted some hearty
column3: not to mention tasty
column4: food before our evening out. We were all running a little late

column6: so good.

column1: The rest of our party arrived and our fabulous server was there to take our orders. Another server brought over a complimentary slice of bruschetta while we waited. Mmmmmm. He brought our drinks

column3: I crumbled and ditched my original choice for the Stuffed Gnocchi with Mushrooms and Sundried Tomatoes in a Rose Sauce($22). My friends ordered Spaghetti Mare Di Mario(seafood in spaghetti for $25)
column4: Salisiccia E Quaglia Alla Griglia(4 types of meat for $28) and Bomba Pizza(cheese
column5: green peppers
column6: sausage
column7: onions for $18).

column1: After the bruschetta and trying to abstain from eating a whole loaf of bread
column2: the food arrived. Hot and smelling amazing. After we were all done taking photos of each other's food
column3: the table fell silent as we dug in. After we all tasted our food
column4: we proceeded to share it. SO good. Healthy portions allowed us to share it without any of us feeling guilty. Everyone agreed my Gnocchi was to die for. The pizza was perfect; thin crust and lots of toppings. The 4 meat dish was polished off. All meats were seasoned perfectly. The seafood pasta had a heap of pasta under those clams!

column1: We were all so full
column2: dessert wasn't even an option. The wine list was delightful. They offered perfect wines to compliment any meal Fieramosca has to offer.

column1: Service was excellent. Great timing
column2: didn't abandon us
column3: but didn't bug us. Dcor was classic and it didn't feel crowded even though it's a smaller space.

column1: A great start to the evening! Full and ready to continue our night out!"
Fieramosca	5	2018-09-14	"Very nice quaint Italian bistro known for it's authentic food. The owners close in August to return to Italy and refresh their menu.
The wine list is diverse from a few regions and wide range of prices. Many great selections that are reasonable.
The food menu has many different choices of pastas and meats.
We had the mozzarella and tomatoes which unfortunately was pretty dry and tasteless. Salt and balsamic to sage the day!

My wife had a fusilli with chicken and eggplant in a pink sauce that was excellent. I had the spaghetti with shrimp and chicken with a garlic white wine sauce that I smelled the second I walked thru the door. It was amazing!! Spot on in every way.
We were sitting for a while talking to a regular guest of the place (3-4x/week) and the owner sat down and talked with us
column2: as she does with many of the guests. After a few minutes she said she was going into the kitchen for desert. She brought out a slice of heaven!! A tiramisu that is to die for!! Light
column3: sweet and aromatic of espresso
column4: of course homemade. A superb ending to a wonderful meal.

column1: This is a gem of a restaurant. Need reservations."
Fieramosca	2	2019-01-29	"I have one question: who are you people who gave this a 4 or 5 star rating??????

We visited for dinner on Saturday evening. When the server appeared to fill our water glasses using a plastic pitcher we knew it was a bad sign. Most disappointing dining experience. We made the reservation based on reviews. I'm simply shocked this restaurant has a 4.5 rating. The food attempts to be high end fine cuisine but is really just pretending. We had the caprese salad. The tomatoes were large (rock) hard basic garden tomatoes - served freezing cold. The mozzarella was rubbery
column2: not creamy like a caprese salad should be. The arugula was a basic run-of-the-mill salad. Excessive and boring. I had the black cod special. The portion was huge and that was all it had going for it. The cod was served on a big bowl full of under cooked garden vegetables (carrots and cauliflower) with watery-tomato sauce. It was a dish you'd expect at a family restaurant chain. It wasn't served how black cod should be. My husband's excessive serving of orecchette was bland and served in a bowl of liquid.

column1: The only positive feedback we can share...the martinis were delicious and the server was lovely and friendly.
It was a cold evening but the dining room was uncomfortably cold and the washrooms were FREEZING.  Yes
column2: it was a very cold evening in the city but this is a restaurant - it should at least be warm. I understand the restaurant has been around for over 30 years - they've had plenty of time to figure out the heating.

column1: The dining room is old and tired
column2: not in a charming way. There was paint peeling from the ceiling above us. We were seated at a table beside a shelf loaded with about 100 bottles of wine that hadn't been dusted in the restaurant's 30years. I've not seen a worse display of wine.

column1: I loved that it was a family-owned restaurant - that's whey we went. It's low end and overpriced. This is not a Yorkville-grade restaurant. Save your money."
Fieramosca	3	2016-07-03	"You take the good

column1: Have you ever gone to a restaurant with great expectations based on reviews and left disappointed?  That was our experience.
Some call it cozy but for me the table layout in the main dining room is claustrophobically cramped.  If you want a seat on the patio on Friday or Saturday in the summer
column2: make sure to reserve several days in advance.

column1: Reservations are taken by phone and I will admit they were very helpful even if it did take 10 rings for them to answer... I was surprised that a restaurant in this price range did not have online reservations!
Being in a house transformed into a restaurant

column3: so if someone is going out

column1: So if you are even a little claustrophobic

column1: The food:
Complimentary bruschetta:  A plain Pizza crust with bruschetta topping which falls off and wasn't that flavourful. Go to La Bruschetta to find out how it is meant to taste.
Caesar salad:  Crispy romaine
column2: hints of fresh garlic and Parmesan but the dressing seemed watery and the croutons were like rocks.

column1: Bread basket:  Now I know why the croutons are like rocks
column2: the crust on the bread was so hard I was worried I would break a tooth
column3: and I also found it strange to be served whole wheat bread
column4: when I was expecting crusty Italian bread.

column1: Spaghetti Carbonara:   The reason we came was because Hubby was craving Carbonara and based on great reviews we thought we would try it here but he found Fieramosca's version disappointingly bland
column2: even with extra Parmesan cheese and fresh ground pepper.

column1: Linguini DI Mamma Ninetta:  I love mushrooms but was surprised that there were so many in this dish... With just 3 small shrimp and a few small pieces of chicken scattered throughout
column2: and very little garlic flavour
column3: this dish was edible but far from great.

column1: Tiramisu:  No coffee flavour!  I have made Tiramisu before and have had it in countless restaurants and I know the lady fingers are to be dipped in coffee before being covered in cream
column2: and these missed the coffee altogether
column3: and the cream here seemed to just be whipped cream
column4: none of the yummy marscapone that I was expecting.   Libretto's Tiramisu in a jar might not be traditional in presentation but has all the flavour that Fieramosca's lacked.  My favourite dessert when done well
column5: I left disappointed.

column1: Lemon Sorbet:  Frozen sorbet in a scooped out lemon
column2: menu says imported from Italy.  I actually liked it better than the sad face Tiramisu so hubby swapped with me because while he usually loves anything lemon
column3: he found an odd aftertaste.  I joked it was the jet fumes to bring frozen sorbet from Italy but the truth is
column4: it was the perfume worn by the woman at the table next to ours.  Thankfully she arrived as we had dessert
column5: so our entire meal was not ruined
column6: but the smell was so overpowering that it gave us both a headache and we wanted to get out of there fast
column7: since with the cramped layout she was almost on top of our table.

column1: Ladies
column2: please don't drown yourself in perfume and go to a restaurant!  Ugh!

column1: TL;DR - Meh. Bottom line nothing was horrible but nothing was great
column2: which for the price was disappointing.  Not worth a second visit.

column1: 2 stars bumped to 3 because the service was good.

column1: Blu Ristorante	5	2019-06-25	"I love this venue so much. We rented out the entire place for a VIP dinner after a conference

Blu Ristorante	3	2019-09-15	"I'm really not trying to be passive aggressive but honestly
column2: this is my interpretation of this restaurant and the patrons who have rated it so highly.  I feel it received the acclamation it has (voted one of most romantic restaurants in the city and all the 5 star ratings) because (a)  it's in Yorkville and (b) guests MAY mostly include those that don't dine out in the city as often.  The ones that usually do on special occasions

column1: Look
column2: this city has an abundance of fantastic restaurants led by a generation of daring
column3: creative and exciting chefs.  So when I come to Blu
column4: that is a self proclaimed ""fine dining"" restaurant
column5: I'm expecting everything to be elevated.  Not everyone can be Alo
column6: I get it
column7: but it's the expectation that's set which I'm comparing the experience to.

column1: For starters we got carpaccio
column2: tuna tartar and the octopus. The carpaccio was your typical combination of flavors that I can recite in my sleep (meet
column3: Capers
column4: some creamy sauce
column5: truffle oil
column6: arugula for garnish.  Maybe not exactly but you know what I mean).  The tartar was tasty from what I recall but the ""octopus"" omg.  First off they seemed to be 2 squid tentacles
column7: very small and burnt.  On one side is a pineapple chutney of sorts and on the other side is an eggplant pure.  It's octopus! Can't really mess that up and don't ever pair is with anything so overpowering. The eggplant ok fine maybe but the Indian flavors did not complement the fish at all.

column1: On to main course.  My wife had the wild boar ragu.  First couple of bites and you're thinking wow this is delicious but I could see where my wife was coming from when she said the sweetness in that dish is just too much.  You almost get sick of it near the end.  But she ate most of it and whatever it was fine.  I had the seafood pasta.  It was good.  Fresh seafood
column2: pasta and light olive oil sauce.  Nothing extra just what you'd expect I guess.

column1: The ambiance is great and we loved the service.  They have a nice drink menu and prices were what you'd expect for Yorkville.

Overall is was a great night and my wife and I didn't leave the restaurant angry.  We enjoyed the food but again it's setting the expectation.  Everything we ate tasted like how they should and we've had those same flavors many times before.  but we were expecting more imagination with flavors and presentation.  Unfortunately Blu didn't deliver"

Blu Ristorante	5	2019-03-20	"Five star for the service! One of our two main orders was wrong. The waiter took both dishes away and remade both dishes from scratch to bring to us again. Now that is a service experience worth remembering!

Blu Ristorante	4	2020-02-14	Went tonight for Valentine and first off was a little shocked by the fact that a couple of the main courses were changed.  They swapped out an 8 oz. Thought nothing of it but then desert came and they changed the choice of to a share platter of 4 small items one of which was an unrippened chocolate covered strawberry.  In all fairness the manager came over and saw I was a little bit taken aback by what occured and offered us both a free drink to make it up to us.  Overall experience was nice just hate settling on one menu to be sold a different one.  Would I come again? Definitely but probably not on a set special menu.  A la carte.

Buca Yorkville	3	2019-09-18	"I read a lot of good reviews about Buca and finally decided to give this top 10 restaurants in Canada a try.

column1: We ordered the fish salami platter to share

column1: For dessert

column1: Tiramisu - This dish barely resembled a tiramisu

column1: Torta - I forgot the full name

column1: Buca Yorkville	4	2018-11-20	"I love this location of Buca. The service is always great and the food never disappoints. Lovely ambience as well!

Buca Yorkville	5	2018-11-21	"Amazing fianc chose this restaurant- we love Italian. Welcomed and seated right away for our reservation last night.

column1: Buca Yorkville	5	2020-01-17	I'm not sure the others ~ but I went there on my birthday ~ definitely love their pasta and desert~ a little bit pricy because of the location for sure ~ had great memorial  with my family ~ I wasn't the one to order that night ~ so I'm not sure the name of the dishes I had that night ~
Buca Yorkville	5	2018-12-03	"This is one of my favourite places in Toronto for sure. They do such an amazing job with EVERYTHING. Service is always flawless. Atmosphere is classy and cool.

Buca Yorkville	4	2019-03-04	"This place is fancy and has decent service. Came on a Sunday for brunch and didn't have to wait too long for our table even though we made reservations.
So it was my choice of giving this place a second chance. A few years back we hit up the king west location and were heavily disappointed with the service and food quantity. Put it this way
column2: we had pizza next door after dinner.

column1: For brunch the ambience was quite cozy and there was a good view of outside. Our server was attentive and was willing to accommodate for my wife's cheese limitations.

As a starter we got the black truffle cortini and they were willing to separate in to one without cheese. It was very delicious and heavy in the truffe. Reminds me a bit of France. It went quite well with my cortado.

For the main I ordered the bison and wife had the duck egg pasta. The portions don't seem like a lot but for lunch it felt quite heavy. The duck pasta was creamy and had a distinct duck flavour to it. Pasta was just right with some chew as well. As for the bison
column2: it felt like dinner. The rich and savory taste made every bite lasting in my mouth. In hindsight I should have paired it with some red wine. Both dishes are highly recommended. We left quite satisfied. One regret is we didn't order the famous little buns. Maybe next time"

column1: Buca Yorkville	5	2019-03-27	"Wow!

column2: just amazing... I would recommend it to share it with others and try their amazing duck pasta which is super rich in flavour :) also do not forget to leave some space for dessert!!"

column1: Buca Yorkville	5	2019-05-31	"TL;DR Upscale delicious Italian seafood
After trying the other Buca restaurants (which were fantastic)
column2: we were not disappointed by Buca Yorkville and can totally see why this place is rated in the top 5 for Canada's Top 100 Restaurants. Its quality and flavours are on par with other top-notch restaurants in Canada.

column1: Spot prawn crudo 5/5 - started with spot prawn freshly flown in just a few hours before. You can taste how fresh it is with its sweet notes and tender meat. It is absolutely divine.
Nodini 5/5 - One of our favourite classic dishes from Buca. The bread knots are small spheres fried with light salt and garlic.

Nnocco fritto (squid ink dumplings withtuna n'duja)5/5 - this was our FAVOURITE dish of the night. We had no idea what it us and took Yelp's recommendation for it. It came with 6 little pockets of bread that you can stuff with spicy tuna and n'duja. The flavour and texture was incredible. Definitely give this a try.
polipo e vongole 3/5 - this octopus dish is where things fell flat for us. The octopus was cooked with clams and bone marrow. Both the clamps
column2: bone marrow
column3: and stock were delicious and rich in flavour. However
column4: the octopus itself lacked flavour and char. When you bite into the meat
column5: there was no chew or tenderness
column6: felt very mushy and bland.

column1: Bigoli 5/5 - our second time order the duck egg pasta. This is a must try when you come to the restaurant. The noodles are perfectly al dente and coated in duck offal ragu. If you're weirded out by innards
column2: do not fret as you do not taste the gameyness at all. The sauce is rich and rounded."

column1: Buca Yorkville	2	2019-10-18	We ordered three pasta dishes all of them were mediocre; lobster

column1: Buca Yorkville	4	2019-07-19	"LOUD diners & superb cuisine

column1: Bar Buca	5	2018-12-05	"This place is fantastic! It's a cafe atmosphere that I assume is similar to one in Italy. It's modern with an industrial feel. column1: Fusaros Kitchen	4	2019-05-08	"I've passed by this place so many times but never got to try it until now. The outside looked nothing special but the interior gave off a cozy vibe. The food here is pretty good and the prices are fair.

column2: very lovely evening here last night - the memory of the flavours makes my eyes roll back in my head!

column1: The pastas were really something to write home about!  They were quite salty to me

column5: and the tomatoes in it were magically not acidic.  The bitterness of the rapini cut through the richness very well.  The lasagna was very
column6: very hearty and rich.  At first bite I kind of thought the sauce was too acidic but once you have it with the meat sauce and the cheese inside
column7: it's perfect.  The tartness of the sauce goes perfectly with the meat sauce
column8: which must have been cooked for hours!  I need to re-emphasize how rich and almost heavy the pastas are - the portions are smaller
column9: which is perfect

column4: and quite salty - but good.  The grilled pork chop was delightfully thick and succulent - as juicy as a grilled pork chop could be!  But the braised onion/pepper garnish it came with DELICIOUS.  It was super savoury

column8: they had the delicious grilled flavour - very nice and basic.

column1: We saved the flourless chocolate cake for home because we didn't want to skip it but were too full to have it right away.  It was dense and chocolatey and sweet without being too sweet.  Very good.
Our server was also quite pleasant and patient with us despite our questions and indecisiveness!  I'd love to come back again and I hope to join the cooking class one day! :)"

Famiglia Baldassarre	5	2020-01-30	"All you need to tell me is that there's a secret pasta warehouse serving up the best pasta dishes in Toronto and I will obviously be there. Baldassarre has been supplying many of Toronto's restaurants with traditional fresh pasta of the highest quality since 2010. But you can also go to eat it directly from the source: Leandro Baldassarre's brick warehouse in Davenport. Toronto Life put them at #97 on their The City's 100 Best Restaurants 2018 list. And blogTO named them as the #1 Best Pasta in Toronto.
It almost sounds too easy
column2: but it's not. If you want to try this pasta you're going to have to work for it. (It'll be worth it.) They're only open Tuesday to Friday from 12-2pm. Yep
column3: that's a weekdays-only two hour window. Plus there are only ten seats in the whole restaurant. I got myself all prepared to do this thing on a Tuesday afternoon and rolled up to the manufacturing strip of warehouses around 11:45am. There was already a lineup of around 15 people deep. I added myself to said lineup. One last hoop to keep in mind is that they are an entirely cash-only operation. You've got this. Arrange your life and go eat some pasta!

column1: Once the doors opened at noon it took about 20 minutes to get myself through the queue and up to the counter. While the space is certainly factory-esque
column2: it's also quite bright
column3: airy and fresh. There's a shelf full of merchandise for purchase
column4: four marble tables available for dining
column5: and the rest of the room is their factory space full of staff members busily working away and rows of pasta being produced. The menu changes each day and the current offerings are posted chalkboard-style. You can take your eats to-go but if you choose to eat in the restaurant then you will need to wait for an available table. A staff member will take your phone number and call you when a table is free. I did this and the wait to be seated was only about 15 minutes - faster than I expected. Once seated
column6: my name was called as my dishes became ready.

column1: The menu is very short. Two different pasta dishes are offered daily. In the small Contorni section (side dishes) there was Fior di Latte (housemade mozzarella balls)
column2: Crudo (raw) prosciutto
column3: and a vegetable dish; Cetrioli (field cucumbers). They also offer some Italian sodas to drink and a Dolce (dessert). Taxes are all included which keeps the prices very straight forward.

column1: Of the side dishes
column2: I very nearly ordered the Fior di Latte
column3: but at the last second found myself asking for the Crudo 24 month San Daniele D.O.P. ($9.00). I couldn't say ""no"" to a gorgeous plate of one of the most prestigious varieties of prosciutto. The D.O.P. stands for ""Protected Designation of Origin
column4: a title which is only given to products that depend solely on the area in which the meat is produced. In this case
column5: the meat comes from San Daniele
column6: a small village in Italy's northern region. The taste and texture of this prosciutto was incredible - likely the best that I've ever tasted. A beautiful saltiness permeated the delicate ham and each bite melted in my mouth. I could certainly tell the difference from a cheaper variety
column7: which can sometimes be stringy and chewy. This meat was none of those things
column8: providing a luscious mouthfeel. Sorprendente!

column1: It was clear to me that we would be ordering both pastas
column2: and that's exactly what we did. First
column3: Tonnarelli al Cacio e Pepe (Pecorino + pepper - $13.00). One of my favourite pasta dishes
column4: I was very excited to find this one on the menu. This Roman dish is simply made with cheese and pepper and it is certainly an example of how the most perfect things are the most straight forward ones. The tonnarelli used is an egg pasta from Lazio (the region in which Rome is located)
column5: quite similar to spaghetti. I have eaten this dish in Rome and I have to say that the version at Baldassarre is pretty close to identical. Their pasta was served perfectly al dente with a little bit of a bite. The liberal application of creamy pecorino and sharp pepper produced a beautiful plate that must be tasted.

column1: Next
column2: Perciatelli a la Matriciana (Guanciale
column3: tomato + Pecorino - $14.00). Perciatelli
column4: otherwise known as bucatini
column5: is a thick spaghetti-like pasta with a hole running through the center. It's one of my favourites! Matriciana sauce is essentially a classic meat sauce based on guanciale
column6: cured pork cheek. I really loved this dish and found myself having moments lost within the sublime simplicity. I would've liked for it to be even saucier
column7: however I did appreciate that the pasta itself was the star of the plate.

column1: I should also mention that Baldassarre provides complimentary crusty Italian bread that you are more then welcome to help yourself to. An excellent and necessary item for sopping up every last drop!
While eating at Baldassarre is a bit of an ordeal
column2: I do think that it was worthwhile. I found the prices very reasonable for the level of food quality. They sell their pasta and sauces as well
column3: so you can keep the delicious eats going at home. If you'r"

column1: Famiglia Baldassarre	4	2020-02-09	"Took other yelper's advice and came at 11:30am on a crisp fall Friday. There were approximately 15 people in front of us

column3: ricotta-spinach ravioli in butter and parmesan.

column1: Maybe my anticipation for the fresh mozzerella caused high expectations as I found the cheese mediocre. It was on the firm side and did not have the smooth- chewy texture I was expecting. However
column2: it was quite milky.

column3: it was not overly salt and did not have a raw meat taste.

column1: The ravioli was my favorite dish. The butter parmesan sauce was addictive and thinly coated the ravioli. The filling to pasta ratio was good - it had enough filling to puff up the ravioli yet it did not burst easily. The pasta was cooked al dente.
The tagliatelle ragu was quite good. The tomato from the ragu was a bit tart which kept the dish light. However
column2: I do wish they gave us more sauce.

column1: The staff were polite despite the constant line up out the door for 2 hours. Next time
column2: I hope to try their burrata."

column1: Famiglia Baldassarre	4	2019-06-07	"Finally came here on a Wednesday to try this unassuming fresh pasta place that I've heard so much about! It's tucked into an industrial area that isn't easily accessible (was literally a 40-min subway ride from downtown Toronto)

Eataly	4	2020-01-28	"Eataly is located in the Manulife Centre at the south east corner of Bay and Bloor.
What at this point most likely takes the largest footprint of this facility
column2: it may have been Ashley before the major renovation.  Eataly Toronto is like Eataly Flatiron approximately fifty thousand square feet.  That's quite a footprint considering this is on multiple levels in an uptown location of Bloor-Yorkville.  For Eataly though you need a large footprint to be able to house multiple food counters
column3: restaurants
column4: full blown grocery options
column5: walls of products and a place for cooking classes.

column1: For those that don't know Eataly is basically a huge Italian superstore.  This store may not have everything you're looking for that is Italian in that they don't have Ferarri or Lamborghini for sale but they do have prosciutto from Modena and many other places for that matter.  Looking for Grana Padano or Reggio Parmigiana?  Will a wheel do?  The guy working the cheese counter said somebody came in and bought half a wheel cut lengthwise for a wedding just the other day.

While the place doesn't have Santa Maria Novella like the NYC Flatiron store they do have on premise made beer at the birroteca on the concourse level.  Using Italian hops and other ingredients Eataly Toronto has the only on premise brewery of all the Eataly establishments so that's sort of special.

I had out of town guests and while my wife has been to Eataly Toronto already I had not been so my first visit was going to be with the out of towners.  We spent quite a bit of time at the olive oil wall as they were trying samples and deciding which to get.  My wife picked one she knew she wanted without trying any samples.  My friends tried a variety and eventually bought one and also a bottle of balsamic to go with it.  My friends ended up getting fresh ravioli nearby as well.

It was mid afternoon on a Friday and the pasta and Neapolitan pizza restaurants had some seating but we were already going to eat a few hours later at a place we made reservations for earlier in the day.  I noticed the Roman style pizza bar was quite popular and a quicker option.  I had the Roman pizza in the Eataly in Century City and I prefer it to the Neapolitan actually.  I like the crunch and the variety of slices I can get in one sitting and while Neapolitan doesn't take very long to make the Roman slices are ready.
Overall Eataly is overwhelming.  While I've been to 3 others (NYC - Flatiron
column2: Chicago
column3: LA - Century City) I found Toronto's to be as good as at least Flatiron but less streamlined.  Toronto's version is more like an Ikea gauntlet that makes you go through the entire store to say get to the gelato bar.  At Flatiron and Chicago the Lavazza and gelato can be accessed at the first floor level without having to go all the way in.  The Toronto setup has the caf type areas in the area on the upper level facing Bloor where there's the pasta/pizza area
column4: bar
column5: coffee/dessert stand
column6: Roman pizza all in a corner.

column1: The content of Eataly Toronto is basically all there in an unfamiliar footprint albeit still somewhat organized.  I like this concept and I'll be back to try the other offerings like the pizza and pasta."

The bread came with some really tasty olive oil. The pizza was excellent with generous toppings. I found our pasta good but not great.

WHAT WENT WRONG: The menu had the Burutta for $8. When the receipt came - I did a quick glance and paid the bill. However the total came up higher than I thought it would be I went back to look at the receipt. The Burutta showed up as $18. I did a double take on a new menu from the front desk to make sure it said $8. My server was elsewhere by now. I went to the front to ask the hostess who at this point basically dismissed me with a chuckle that the menu was ""printed wrong"". I was in a rush so left but I would have definitely taken this up with the manager.
I really think they should have just fixed their menu (even just pencilled it in)
column2: or warned me it was a pricing error when I ordered."

Nodo Restaurant	5	2019-01-22	"So much to love about dear Nodo.  The pastas are beautifully simple.  The pizza divine. The service is enthusiastic.  I'm confused by the amuse bouche of the olive oil drenched lupini beans
column2: but no matter.  Here's a little yarn as to why they deserve 5 stars and your business:

column1: After a number of positive experiences
column2: I dropped by to order a couple of pastas to go.  The bartender
column3: who was not busy
column4: was rude and abrasive.  He punched  in my order like a cashier at 7-11 and split.  As he left
column5: I said ""I'd love a glass of wine while I'm waiting."" Which he basically ignored.

column1: The pasta arrived in a bag by a smiling kitchen runner and I got up to leave.  As I left
column2: the manager asked ""how was everything tonight?"" I told him his bartender was an a-hole and was gobsmacked by how terribly he treated me.  His face fell. What happened next was amazing.  The manager couldn't react fast enough
column3: saying it was entirely his fault as he hires the staff that that kind of poor behavior is unacceptable.  He produced a $50 gift card and asked to have another chance to continue to earn my business.

column1: My wife and I came 2 nights later and were enchanted once again.  We're loyal customers for life.

The point I'm trying to make is restaurants have off nights.  The management can screw up.  The chef can drop the ball.  We're all human.  What counts is how management reacts to you IN PERSON gripe.  He was a gentleman and handled us with care.
Going home and giving a restaurant one star because they forgot your dessert is ridiculous.  Saying it's expensive is ridiculous.  The menu is on the door.
Yelp can be somewhat uneven and unfair in this regard which is why we returned and gave them another chance and it was well worth it.
Before you ding a restaurant's Yelp score
column2: talk to the management in person.  If they blow you off
column3: leave them one star.  But in this case of perfectly executed damage control
column4: Nodo gets 5."

La Vecchia Ristorante	4	2019-04-04	"Recently came here with my friends on a saturday night. There's parking along the street and we were lucky to snag a spot close to the restaurant. The restaurant is bigger than it looks on storefront - there's actually two floors! When we first walked in it was kind of awkards becuase i had to check in with the hostess but there's only standing room behind the door and we felt kind of awkward standing there while they figure out which table we were in. They were very accomodating tho - we ran late for about 15 mins past reservation and they saved the table for us.
Our table was actually down the stairs - there was a function that night so it was a bit loud on the main floor
column2: but downstairs it's actually much nicer and quiet. Spacing is a bit tight
column3: but we manage to fit in a baby okay! But i would not recommend bringing in a stroller coz there's no room for that.

column1: Servers and staff were all very nice and friendly. lots of options to choose from - i ordered the special that night which was braised wild boar with polenta and veg. I dont' like polenta
column2: so i asked server if i could substitute with pasta and they were able to do that with no extra charge - i asked for the fresh tegliatelle with tomato sauce. My hubby had their bufala pizza
column3: and my other friends ordered the tegliatelle with funghi
column4: tegliatelle with ragu and another order of the wild boar.

column1: Food was great! we ordered an app to share but in hindsight was not the best choice - ordered the speck and bufala and the portion was kind of small that it was a bit tough to share amongst 5 ppl. but it was very tasty.
Then the mains - they were great on the whole! the pizza was nice and crispy
column2: lots of toppings - the middle was a bit dense tho so the pizza couldn't hold up as well as i would have liked. The wild boar was very delicious and tasty
column3: but i felt the meat was a bit dry
column4: almost tough in certain chunks. They gave me the polenta anyway for presentation purposes (which i gladly took pics of lol) and they served the pasta on the side instead. In general
column5: portions were good. I felt the special the portion was a bit small for it's price point - I woud've been more full with their pasta/pizza options. HOwever
column6: since i did have pasta on the side
column7: I really really liked it. There is a difference in the fresh pasta compared to the dry and my friends really liked the funghi (very tasty mushrooms) and the ragu the meat was soft and moist.

column1: For dessert we ordered the dessert platter for four - which included the panna cotta
column2: tiramisu
column3: chocolate fondant cake and cheesecake.

column1: All four were great - loved sharing it and getting a bit of each. my handsdown favourite was panna cotta. I normally don't like panna cotta
column2: but theirs is so creamy and rich
column3: not too jelly like and the texture and taste BLEW my mind! Tiramisu was good too but wasn't able to outshine the panna cotta. The chocolate cake was delicious and rich. Cheesecake was average (taste just like typical cheesecake so nothing particularly special).

column1: All in all it was a great meal - we stayed for almost 3 hours and they didn't rush us! we were really thankful for that esp since it is a busy night for them. I will definitely be back again soon!"

La Vecchia Ristorante	4	2019-10-05	Amazing gem in the yonge and eglinton neighborhood serving out the best al dente pasta. I ordered their beef brisket ravioli pasta and it was out of this world! It was hitting all 3 S's : SOFT

La Vecchia Ristorante	4	2019-05-20	"La Vecchia has some of the best Italian food I've had in a long time. The seafood pasta is absolutely delicious

column1: La Vecchia Ristorante	3	2018-08-29	"My family and I decided to choose La Vecchia for my mini wedding dinner

Taverna Mercatto	2	2019-12-19	"This is definitely Italian food for the after-work crowd
column2: a Buca di Beppo-type of experience that didn't leave that much of an impression on my palate. It wasn't that the food was badly executed but rather that the plates were by-the-numbers unmemorable. I was here with the same dozen people I had been with for the previous eight hours
column3: so small talk opportunities had already been exhausted as we sat closely together at a communal table. Because of the size of our party
column4: I was able to try quite a number of their dishes and got a reasonably broad cross-section.

column1: The common adjective connecting the plates was 'bland'. We started with the $14 Calamari Fritti which apparently came with shishito peppers that had disappeared by the time the plate was passed to me (photo: http://bit.ly/35MxgSg). Meh. I did manage to snag one of the overly chilled prawns on the $21 Shrimp Cocktail platter (photo: http://bit.ly/2EE5UBy). Better were the $13 Beets & Burrata with arugula and toasted almonds (photo: http://bit.ly/34Lnhva) and the $12 Greens which added celery hearts for crunch and a drizzle of sherry vinaigrette (photo: http://bit.ly/36TVmKG). The pasta plates were pretty standard issue given the couple of bites I was able to get of each.
The $21 Linguine di Mare was a typical seafood melange with little imagination (photo: http://bit.ly/2PGtJ22)
column2: while the $18 Tortiglioni alla Bolognese at least provided meatiness in the veal & pork ragu
column3: but again it was bland and lacked freshness (photo: http://bit.ly/373WnjJ). The three different pizzas disappointed. The $18 Verdure had toppings and a basil pesto that were rather skimpy on the chewy crust (photo: http://bit.ly/38R3Y6R). while the $17 Margherita was just wet (photo: http://bit.ly/2Q1UXzi). Only the $19 Prosciutto was reasonably good with the padano cheese and prosciutto more plentiful (photo: http://bit.ly/34GULe2).

column1: Dessert came on cutting boards
column2: and they offered a trio of which truthfully I only tried the Tiramisu Cake Roll which was OK (photo: http://bit.ly/2M8ukaH). There was also Chocolate Budino and Cannolo though my colleagues grabbed those pretty quickly (photo: http://bit.ly/36UM69j). My favorite part of the meal? The $14 Pimms Cup with ginger ale
column3: lemon & cucumber
column4: which honestly hit the spot far more than any of the food (photo: http://bit.ly/2SarzJH). Listen
column5: none of us had high hopes for culinary delights here
column6: and even our sponsor admitted this was not her first choice
column7: but the proximity to our hotel just made it so convenient.

column1: FOOD - 2.5 stars...standard issue Italian with few surprises
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...loud and rather packed after work
SERVICE - 2 stars...nothing special
TOTAL - 2 stars...not worth seeking out unless your expense account covers it

column1: Taverna Mercatto	4	2019-10-13	"I visited Taverna on a weekday afternoon for a work lunch. There was a large group of around 12 of us there that afternoon. We had made a reservation in advance so we had no issues getting a table.
The menu was pretty expansive and had a nice selection of salads
column2: antipasti
column3: pizzas and pastas. The table got a nice variety of pizzas and pastas. I went with the Bianca pizza with potatoes and mushrooms and caramelized onions. For servicing such a big group
column4: the food arrived quickly which was something important to us since we had to get back to work!

column1: My pizza was excellent. A nice balance of sweetness from the onions as well as a savoury flavour from the mushrooms and cheese. The cheese on the pizza was quite strong (I think it was Gorgonzola) so it added nice flavour to the pizza without overpowering it. The crust was also very thin and cooked well without being burnt or crispy. The size of the pizza was also great. I was able to get through 3 slices and have a couple left over to take home :) The others from my table also commented on their pastas being well cooked and flavourful.
What really stole the show was the dessert. We weren't planning on getting dessert but when the server explained to us what was on the menu
column2: we couldn't resist. A few of us got the gelato trio which came with a little biscotti on the side. I went with the pistachio orange cannoli and omg it was incredible. The pastry cream on the inside was sweet and also tarte with a refreshing orange flavour. The pistachios added a nice crunch and the cannoli shell was also sweet and slightly flaky. I highly recommend getting dessert here!

column1: For a work lunch or even a nice date
column2: I think Taverna is a great spot for authentic Italian food at an affordable pricepoint."

column1: Taverna Mercatto	5	2019-05-04	"Was craving some good old pasta as we tumbled upon this italian restaurant while looking for an early dinner before seeing a show at the Scotiabank Arena (literally only a 5 minute walk). Came here for the first time on a friday evening around 5:30pm

column1: We ordered the Arancini appetizer to share
column2: and i was tempted to get another order! I highly recommend you to try this appetizer. It's really easy to share as well
column3: it comes with 3 pieces of deep fried mushroom risotto balls with a delicious spicy tomato sauce that accompanies it perfectly. I was so sad when the waiter took away the plate so quickly before I could get the rest of the tomato sauce!

column1: We also ordered the carbonara and bolognese pastas to share. Their pasta is perfectly cooked al dente and the flavours are well balanced. Having recently returned from Italy a few months ago
column2: this place really does compare. Tables around me all ordered pizzas and they looked pretty good
column3: will definitely try it next time i come back.

The staff was very nice and accommodating.

column1: When we first got there my husband and I ordered drinks. He got a Old-Fashioned and I got a Sangria. He enjoyed his drink. My drink started off good but then started to taste like medicine the more I drank it. Needless to say I didn't finish it.

We started our dinner with ordering the Kale as an appetizer. Of course this was a side salad. It consisted of shaved kale with pinenuts and cranberries covered with pecorino cheese in a lemon and olive oil dressing. This salad was very good. The flavors were nice and most of all I enjoyed the pinenuts. They added a nice crunch to the dish.
For our entrees I ordered the STRO ZZAPRETI ALLA ERNESTO and my husband ordered the Roasted Chicken Breast. My dish consisted of spicy nduja sausage
column2: rapini and cherry tomatoes in garlic and olive oil. This was something different for me but good. The sausage added a nice hint of heat but not too spicy. The pasta was good. It also had cherry tomatoes and spinach. I could have done without the spinach. I like spinach in salads or creamed spinach but I don't like plain cooked down spinach. The texture is odd in my opinion. Other than that this dish was good.  My husband's dish came with vegetables and roasted potatoes. The chicken was pretty tender but flavorless. The whole plate was flavorless for that matter. It was very bland and needed seasoning. My husband ate it but he wasn't thrilled.

column1: Last

column1: Overall

column1: Giulietta	5	2020-05-23	"Giulietta is located on College about a short walk from Dovercourt. I had been wanting to try this restaurant for a while as I had heard good things. I decided to order takeout as Giulietta started offering this amidst the pandemic. Online ordering was a breeze on their website where I selected a particular pick up time. The pick up experience was good but I had to wait for a few minutes for my order to come out.

I ordered the crab spaghetti and the ravioli girasole. The crab spaghetti had large chunks of crab meat and the sauce complimented and coated the fresh housemade pasta well. What a delicious dish! The ravioli girasole was also a great dish as well
column2: very bright and had a lot of lemon flavour without it being overpowering. Overall
column3: both pasta dishes were outstandingly delicious and simplistic in a good way. Would definitely come back to Giulietta for more!"

column1: Giulietta	4	2020-01-30	"Giulietta has been high on my to-do list because I hear about it everywhere. Not only am I an avid fan of Top Chef Canada
column2: where in season one Executive Chef Rob Rossi was the runner-up (he was my favourite on the show and should've won!) but the hype is real about this place in general. enRoute magazine chose them as #5 on Canada's Best New Restaurants 2018 list. Toronto Life has them on two lists; #33 on The City's 100 Best Restaurants 2018 and #3 on The Best New Restaurants 2019. And of course
column3: the biggest of them all
column4: they've landed at #9 on Canada's 100 Best Restaurants 2019. It has all certainly been more than enough to catch my attention. Giulietta (pronounced Julietta) is an Italian restaurant set on making classic dishes fresh and new again. And I was lucky enough to pay them a visit on a Saturday evening for my anniversary
column5: no less.

column1: The outside of this Little Italy-adjacent restaurant is fairly unassuming
column2: however the inside is very sharp. A reservation is almost always a must. A lot of care and attention has gone into the stylish design of the space
column3: creating a polished atmosphere. Muted tones are accented with copper metallics
column4: with just a little bit of exposed brick for good measure. I was impressed by the stunning glass walk-in pantry placed right in the middle of the room. This truly added a market-quality feeling to the space and certainly invoked a certain Italian vibe. I also noted the various bar carts around the room
column5: stocked full with gleaming bottles and glasses. The room feels quite adult and a little like an escape to Europe.

column1: Seated at our cozy table for two
column2: I eyed up the bustling activity in the open kitchen. Chef Rob Rossi himself did not appear to be present on this evening. Next
column3: a thorough examination of the cutlery was in order. This might be one of the best little features to discover at Giulietta - many of the mismatched vintage flatwear are engraved with all sorts of adorable little sayings. I had a fork which read ""me too"" and an appropriately-printed spoon that said ""spoon me."" I absolutely loved this whimsical touch. Our friendly hostess and server wished us a happy anniversary repeatedly
column4: which was incredibly sweet. I appreciated that there was no pretension to be found whatsoever
column5: but on the other hand
column6: I found the service almost slightly too casual. I liked that our server was quite laid-back but I found her delivery of information somewhat unpolished for a restaurant of this caliber. We were offered complimentary sparkling or still water to drink.

column1: I was ready for a cocktail and easily selected the Giulietta Spritz (Quaglia berto aperitivo
column2: prosecco & soda - $15.00) with the assumption that any signature drink has gotta be good. Made with a classic Italian aperitif
column3: I loved the light
column4: fresh bitterness. The essence was reminiscent of chinotto to me - one of my favourite flavours to accompany Italian food. The olive garnish was the perfect touch and the fact that I was provided with a small gold-rimmed dish for the pit was even better. Saluti!

column1: The copper-embossed menu is one page long with well-laid out sections. It reads as an Italian meal should be consumed; with Primi
column2: Secondi
column3: and Contorni columns. Our server was helpful in suggesting some of the restaurant's top plates and my husband and I did our best to make well-rounded selections
column4: attempting to taste as much variety as possible. Starting with the Spuntini (snacks) section
column5: the Olive all' Ascolana (Fried Castelvetrano olives wrapped with sausage - $9.00) seemed like an obvious choice. This little dish was unexpected. I've never tried a sausage-wrapped olive before and I was here for it. Dusted with Pecorino
column6: these savoury-briny bites were fried to perfection and incredibly unique.

column1: From the same section
column2: we also chose the Burrata Pugliese (Italian Burrata
column3: rhubarb marmellata
column4: gnocco fritto
column5: black pepper & basil - $27.00). It was easy to be enticed by the grilled octopus
column6: but I had a good feeling about this one. I mean
column7: gnocco fritto is always a major selling point in my book. Doesn't everyone love fried pillows of happiness? Burrata is a fresh Italian cow milk cheese made from mozzarella and cream. The result is an ultra-soft
column8: practically spreadable cheese that tastes like heaven when seasoned with a bit of olive oil and salt. The gnocco fritto served as a vessel for the Burrata and a bit of rhubarb jam on top added a delightful tart sweetness. This is the perfect example of a plate that is so simple
column9: and yet so perfect. I think that this dish was our favourite of the entire meal.

column1: Moving to the Primi (first) section
column2: it was time to get things going for real. All four pasta dishes on offer sounded amazing
column3: but the Tonnarelli Cacio e Pepe (Traditional long Roman pasta
column4: kampot black pepper & Pecorino - $23.00) had to be the one. My husband and I adored this dish on our trip to Rome a few years ago and have a definite soft spot for it. An extremely simple pasta
column5: it basically just involves cheese and pe"

column1: Giulietta	5	2019-12-15	"Wow wow wow.

column1: Giulietta	4	2019-01-06	"Part of a longer review...

Pai Northern Thai Kitchen	5	2020-03-07	"Bold flavours and a electric atmosphere make Pai a go to if you're craving Thai in Toronto. The dishes are full of flavour and the pleasant heat that comes with Northern Thai food specifically. The beef curry that I had was rich without being overpowering

Seven Lives Tacos y Mariscos	4	2020-01-30	"Knowing where to get the best tacos in town is serious business. As it stands
column2: the best tacos that I have ever eaten have been at Tacofino in Tofino and Tres Carnales Taquera in Edmonton. After reading that Seven Lives was voted #1 Best Taco 2018 by NOW Toronto
column3: named in National Geographic magazine's Places of a Lifetime article
column4: and called #1 Best Fish Taco and #1 Best Tacos by blogTO... They seemed like a sure bet.

column1: You'll find Seven Lives located in Kensington Market
column2: one of the most eclectic corners of the city which suits them well. I visited the tiny shop on a Friday evening
column3: prior to their early closing time of 7pm. They're definitely more of a lunch or early dinner type of place. It should also be noted that they accept cash only
column4: so come prepared!

column1: The tiny shop is bustling and exciting
column2: buzzing with taco energy. The bright walls and giant sign that reads ""TACOS"" sets the vibe perfectly. I also appreciate their logo of a cat with a fish in its mouth - and the insinuation that this cat is down to seven lives
column3: having already lost two. There is one table that can seat about four people and then there's a little bit of standing-room-only counter space. This makes things a little bit awkward if you plan to eat-in
column4: as I did. The table wasn't available and so I stood at the counter in front of the window to eat instead. Which was fine. But certainly not ideal.

column1: The menu is fairly straight forward
column2: including nine types of tacos
column3: some sides
column4: and some beverages. Your order is placed at the counter with a friendly staff member and they call out your name once the food is ready.

column1: Starting with something to drink
column2: I was happy to see Agua de Jamaica on the menu. I always prefer an agua fresca when visiting a Mexican establishment
column3: although I was also happy to see that Jarritos Mexican sodas are also on offer. (Their cola is my personal favourite of all of the colas.) Agua de Jamaica
column4: otherwise known as ""hibiscus water"" is a beverage that exists in several cultures. In Southeast Asia it is known as Rosella tea and it's basically the same thing. Tart and sweet
column5: this refreshing drink was a perfect accompaniment to the food.

column1: We decided to get a Side as a bit of an appetizer. Tortilla Chips (Made fresh! - $3.00) and Guacamole ($3.00 for small) seemed like the way to go. I was a bit surprised that the guacamole didn't just come with tortilla chips and that both items had to be purchased separately. However
column2: I did enjoy the homemade nature of the chips and that a heaping amount of them are tossed into a brown paper bag and given to you. I'll take a bag of chips any day. Golden and ultra crispy
column3: these tortilla chips are exactly what I wanted them to be. They were seasoned really nicely as well. The guacamole was fresh and bright
column4: with a great acidic kick to it. Obviously chips and guac are a match made in heaven.

column1: Next it was time for the big show: the TACOS. Of the nine tacos available
column2: two of them (the Adobada and the Carnitas) were already sold out. On the plus side
column3: I probably wouldn't have ordered either of these anyway. Although
column4: I must say that this did not leave much for meat options. There were four fish/seafood tacos
column5: one beef and one chicken option
column6: and a vegetarian. Nothing for pork at all. But again
column7: I did not mind at all because I was going full ocean food - it's what they specialize in
column8: after all.

column1: Baja Fish ($6.00) and Gobernador ($6.00) were the ones for me. I loved the little condiments bar to the left of the counter that featured three different salsas (hot habanero
column2: medium tomatillo
column3: mild guajillo) as well as chili oil with sesame
column4: and a bowl of sliced limes. This makes it very easy to customize your tacos to your preferred specifications and to control the amount of heat that you desire.

column1: The tacos did not take very long and before I knew it
column2: a green plastic basket was placed in my hands. The tacos were certainly vibrant and demanding to be eaten.

column1: I began with the Gobernador (smoked marlin
column2: shrimp & cheese). If Seven Lives has a signature taco
column3: this is the one. Their front window even says ""home of the Gobernador"" right on it. I definitely loved the smokiness from the marlin the most
column4: while the shrimp filled out the taco and added more texture. Everything had been grilled up deliciously. The pickled onion brought a great hit of balancing flavour and I liked the fresh tortillas a lot.

column1: Next I had the Baja Fish (fried haddock). The first thing that I noticed is how generous the portion of fish is! The haddock was big
column2: juicy and fried to perfection. The rest of the taco was kept very fresh with cabbage and fresh homemade salsa on top.

column1: Both tacos were packed full and were pretty messy to eat
column2: but in the best possible way. I liked both tacos but found them to be missing something that I can't quite put my finger on. I guess that I was hoping for something even bigger and more unexpected in terms of flavour. They were good... Just not the best that I've ever had.

column1: I was also very impressed to see a C"

column1: Seven Lives Tacos y Mariscos	5	2019-08-18	"I expected to experience a lot of exceptional food while in Toronto for a few days
