column1: This place is the definition of a hidden gem.  It's a small place nestled in a plaza at Midland and McNicoll.  The place is super tiny
column2: just enough to fit everything in.  There's 2 chairs and a aisle to sit if you really want
column3: but take out is the way to go.

column1: What stands out immediately is the prices.  Most places now charge close to $10 or more for a pound of BBQ pork.  The price here
column2: $7.50.  You're not comprising quality here for the price too.  The meats here are just as good as anywhere else.  You'll find the prices are about 2 to 3 dollars cheaper across the board for everything you usually find at a Chinese BBQ place.

column1: 2 things stand out for me the most here.  First
column2: they have a curry beef brisket.  It's hard to find Chinese BBQ places that to curry beef brisket anymore.  It used to be more frequent but most places have stopped doing it.  You get a large order here for $8.50
column3: that's a win.

column1: Second
column2: the service her is amazing.  I usually get my BBQ pork a little on the fatty side.  When I placed my order
column3: the butcher took a look and couldn't find any.  Rather than try to sell me something I didn't want and pretend it was still fatty
column4: he honestly told me he didn't have any and asked if I wanted to wait 10 minutes for some new ones that would be fatty.  Let me tell you
column5: most places would not do that.  They would of just chose something remotely close to what I wanted and that would be that.  The fact that he was so honest about what he's selling impressed the heck out of me.

column1: The only thing bad I can say about this place is the cash only policy but that's nothing new for these kind of places.
I love Ho Ho Barbeque.  Like I said
column2: it's my new go to for Chinese BBQ and any fan should definitely try this place out as well."

Shuan Tofu Sheets: Again
column2: another OK dish but wasn't amazing. While the flavor is there from the peanut and sesame sauce
column3: the texture of the tofu was off-putting after a few strands. We didn't finish the dish.

column1: If you're looking for spicy noodles
column2: give this restaurant a try. Otherwise
column3: tons more noodle places to eat around Yonge-Dundas."

column1: Artisan Plus	3	2019-07-28	"Relatively new noodle spot that opened up downtown just at Bay and Dundas. Came by with a few coworkers for lunch and the consensus was that it was okay.
Even though Artisan plus was packed when we arrived. We were lucky and was able to get seated fairly quickly for a party of 6.
We were seated on the high top right in front of the kitchen and got to witness the staff in action. It still amazes me how efficient the kitchen works
column2: it's a well oiled machine.

column1: I ordered the appetizer trio
column2: pork bun
column3: and clam mashi. The appetizer trio was a combo of enoki
column4: bean curd
column5: and tripe. Of the 3 the tripe stood out the most. The bean curd and enoki mushroom were okay at best. The trio comes with dipping sauce that tasted very similar to a peanut sauce.

column1: The pork bun was shared among the group and we found that although the pork was really flavourful and moist
column2: the bun itself was a tad on the dry side. Not the good kind either. It's worth a try but I wouldn't be ordering this again if I visited again.

column1: The clam mashi was amazing! I've gotta say I could have done with without the other two items on the menu but the clam mashi is a must. Be warned
column2: it's a little spicy. I would say out of 10
column3: would be about a 7 on my scale. Not to the point where the heat was unbearable and unenjoyable. It definitely lingers and I found myself going through water pretty quickly. The clams were declines in the dish and there was quite a few in there to enjoy. This was my first time having mashi and I'm now a big fan of that."

column1: Artisan Plus	4	2020-01-03	"A solid spot for hand-pulled noodles. I got the wok cumin che mian with beef. There's a lot of well-integrated flavour in the bowl. It's pricey ($16 for what I got) and portions aren't massive
column2: but it sure is tasty."

column1: Artisan Plus	5	2019-05-07	"I have been here twice already after they opened

column1: Second time here

column5: ITS SOOOOOOOOO GOOOOOOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I have never had mashi like this and I'm really impressed!!! I will definitely come back for more of this!!!!!!!!"

column1: Artisan Plus	3	2019-08-12	"Tried out this newish place at bay and Dundas. The menu describes the food as northern Chinese and simple. While the ingredients are all fresh
column2: I think they've taken the ""simple"" a bit too far. I tried the short-rib beef dish. The broth is basic and does not have much flavour. That said
column3: the veggies were all fresh and delicious. Just needed a bit more flavour to kick the dish up a notch.

column1: Decor-wise
column2: the place is hip and modern. Staff are all very friendly and can explain the dishes. Food comes out fast. May try this place again and try a different dish"

column1: Artisan Plus	5	2019-06-23	"Sooooooo. Good. No joke
column2: I visited this restaurant and came back for more only 2 days later.

column1: I am so glad that regional Chinese cuisine is exploding onto Toronto's food scene. Don't get me wrong
column2: dim sum is alright
column3: but biang biang noodles are where it's at.

column1: And they are so damn good here. Thick handmade noodles
column2: enveloped in warm sweet and savoury sauce
column3: and served with a generous variety of toppings -- it's just so comforting. I inhaled everything on my plate in record time. I think the $13.99 price point is fair.

column1: The other standout for me was the Shuan Platter ($12.99). It's an appetizer sampler with enoki mushrooms
column2: tofu sheets
column3: and honeycomb tripe doused in chili sesame sauce. Just thinking about the tripe makes my mouth water -- the soft
column4: chewy tripe was the perfect vessel for soaking up the rich sauce. Umami galore.

column1: Pretty much everything else we've tried so far has been delicious
column2: except perhaps the shredded potato salad ($5.99
column3: not pictured). It was a little too vinegary and not spicy enough for my taste
column4: but still complemented the Jia Mo well.

column1: The ambiance is definitely fast-paced during busy prime hours
column2: so come during off peak periods (before 6 pm
column3: after 8:30 pm) to skip the lineups. Service is quite good and
column4: unlike similar restaurants
column5: the servers speak fluent English.

column1: Can't get enough of this place! Try it and thank me later."
Artisan Plus	4	2019-05-01	"I highly recommend this restaurant if you want to try North-West Chinese eats that are different from usual westernized Chinese food (aka fried rice
column2: General Tao
column3: etc.)

column1: My first impression was the interior - very bright and modern with transparent glass stools
column2: unlike other typical Chinese restaurants that run on a warm and cozy vibe. Even though the restaurant looked spacious from outside
column3: it was actually quite tight with limited seats.

column1: Since it was our first visit
column2: we opted for the restaurant's bestsellers
column3: which were beef Yopo BiangBiang (wide flat noodles) and Pork JiaMo (pork bun). The noodles arrived quickly after 5 minutes with tomato scrambled egg
column4: braised beef
column5: and assortments of vegetables (cubed potatoes
column6: carrots
column7: ear fungus
column8: edamame
column9: zucchini). At first
column10: I thought the combination of ingredients was peculiar; however
column11: it turned out to be absolutely delicious as different flavors really complimented each other. I also enjoyed their chewy ""ribbon noodles""! If you are not able to handle spicy food like I am
column12: I'd recommend asking the waitress for no (or less) chilli flakes since they really added some intense heat to the dish. The pork JiaMo was good as well - the shredded meat was well-marinated.

column1: We visited a few days after Grand Opening and the restaurant was quite packed. However
column2: service was still quick and efficient.

column1: A bonus point is that Artisan Plus is vegan-friendly!
I'd love to come back to try other different North-Western Chinese food!"

column1: When it came time to order our meal

column1: Artisan Plus	4	2019-06-10	"Great place in the heart of Toronto dt! I recently discovered XiAn food and this restaurant did not disappoint. They made the space quite fun. Their biangbiang noodles were tasty and I loved trying all the toppings with it. Nice punch with the heat.

Lai Wah Heen	4	2019-11-29	"Located on the second floor of DoubleTree By Hilton hotel is Lai Wah Heen
column2: a premium dim sum restaurant. The restaurant is clean and elegant with original Chinese calligraphy paintings. I have dined here for dim sum on a few occasions

column4: most recently
column5: I finally tried their dinner menu. It contains a variety of classic dishes and some more imaginative items. They are also now serving casserole dishes.

column1: Got the Casserole of Lobster

column1: Lai Wah Heen	3	2020-05-17	"I give this restaurant three stars. I have been to Lai Wah Heen twice

column1: The dim sum is very good but there aren't many

We particularly liked the crispy shrimp rolls served with sweet hawthorn sauce and the sticky rice filled with assorted seafood & meat

column1: I will likely return to Lai Wah Heen sometime in the near future. I recommend this restaurant to anyone that likes dim sum and wants experience eating it in a high end setting. Three stars."

Lai Wah Heen	4	2019-08-16	"There's really too many good dim sum places in the GTA so it's really hard to say that this place is phenomenal.  It's located on the 2nd floor of DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel.   I love the ambiance here and it's a great place for a business lunch.  If your office is connected to the PATH

column3: exit the doors of the Sheraton parking lot that takes you up to City Hall and then its another 5 mins walk.

column1: I've been here many times for dim sum and it is always consistently very good.  A recent reviewer mentioned that the skin was a bit thick on the steamed dumpling.  I have to admit that it was on the chewier side but the shrimp inside was very tasty!  The siu mai and the fried shrimp balls are my favorite!  The dishes are a bit pricey for about $9.50 a dish which makes it even harder to say it's worth it.   But given that there aren't too many dim sum restaurants around the core financial district

column1: Lai Wah Heen	3	2019-07-26	"Came to Lai Wah Heen with my family to try out their peking duck as I had received a coupon for a free order. Growing up in Scarborough and being completely surrounded by Chinese restaurants
column2: and being Chinese myself
column3: I've had my fair share of Chinese cuisine. Upon arrival
column4: I knew right away it would be a different vibe as it was located inside a hotel and everything looked fairly nice.

column1: The staff was helpful and polite though a bit stiff. Nonetheless our order was accurate and the tea was always filled. We had dinner on a Tuesday night so it wasn't overly busy but there were some larger parties dining.
On to the food: so as I said
column2: I'm Chinese and have grown up around eating this food in and outside of the house. We ordered about 9 dishes for 7 people including peking duck
column3: stir-fried beef flavoured with aged mandarin peel

The taste though was really really good. Everything was delicious and had lots of flavour. Presentation was pretty and at the end we ordered enough to feel full though not without a price.

column1: Overall
column2: the food was delicious
column3: the service was good but price for the amount of food was just a bit too much for myself. They are other options out there for upscale Chinese food that might possibly be less expensive and closer to my neck of the woods."

column1: Lai Wah Heen	4	2019-04-03	"I recently attended a dinner at Lai Wah Heen with 9 others. We had made a reservation with the expectation of having a set dinner
column2: but when we arrived
column3: we discovered the menu we had been looking at online was no longer available. We were presented with a few other options and in the end
column4: we selected one that everyone could agree on.

column1: This was my first time trying sea cucumber and I'm not sure I'll be jumping at a chance to have it again. The texture was really strange
column2: and it kind of reminded me of chewing on cartilage. Not my favourite
column3: let's leave it at that. My favourite dishes of the evening were the scallops and prawns
column4: the Wok-baked lobster and the fried rice with foie gras. They were packed with flavour and left me wanting more. Every dish was quite good
column5: actually - those were just the standout ones for me.

column1: The dessert was a bit weird
column2: based on comments from a few people in my group. The dessert trio included a soup that consisted of sweetened red bean
column3: which is quite typical for a Chinese dessert and there was a sesame ball with taro inside (I loved this) and a strawberry jelly roll
column4: which I didn't really care for
column5: and was apparently the strangest item in our entire meal
column6: after a very interesting conversation about Chinese desserts.

column1: Service was really good. There were a few people taking care of us
column2: which helped speed things along when it came to plating the food. They would first bring the large platter to our table so we could see (take photos!) and then swiftly move to a serving cart beside our table and divided everything up between 10 dishes. I much prefer this to letting us serve ourselves
column3: and I wish more places would do this. It takes away any chance of someone feeling slighted if
column4: for example

column6: or the 'best' piece of chicken.

column1: It was a pricey meal

column1: Lai Wah Heen	4	2017-09-08	"Lets face it
column2: dim sum can be a stressful experience. The waiting
column3: crowds
column4: loud noises and rushed service can all be off-putting. It may be a big price to pay for those delicious Chinese tapas that we call  dim sum.

column1: Some may argue these unpleasantries are part of the quintessential dim sum experience
column2: but I disagree. I don't like crowds and I don't like noise
column3: so typically I stay away from dim sum. Lai Wah Heen is an exception to the typical Dim Sum experience.

column1: Dim sum at Lai Wah Heen is more like a High Tea experience. It's mostly calm and soothing. The service is impeccable with attentive uniformed waiters. The ambiance is upscale with white tablecloth and minimal ambient noise.

It's pricier than average dim sum. True. But you get what you pay for. All the dishes are very good. The clay pot eel rice is delicious as is the steamed bean curd sheet wrapped with mushrooms. My gf's favorite dish was the steamed chicken with fish maw in rice wine sauce.
Now that my mother lives in condominium close by
column2: Lai Wah Heen may be my new go-to for some ""peaceful"" dim sum. It may be more expensive
column3: but it's worth it in my opinion

Lai Wah Heen	5	2017-08-01	"I'm surprised to read all these contrasting
